Dear Amanda Waidelich:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not
result in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A has ringworm covering his whole body including a golf
ball-sized circle that has puss on the side of his head. There are at
least 15 spots of ringworm on him.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via phone on 10/4/2023. He
reported being the father of Youth A. During a visit on 10/3/23 he
cut Youth A’s hair and noticed a sore on Youth A’s head. When he
2

gave Youth A a shower, he noticed several sores on Youth A’s
body. He also reported visiting with Youth A weekly (Sundays)
since the beginning of the year and has noticed red marks and
bruising on Youth A. Youth A has a history of self-harm (biting and
hitting himself) which cause the marks Complainant has observed.
This time, Complainant reported Youth A had ring worm and not
eczema as reported by the facility. He reported being told by Case
Manager the doctor diagnoses the marks as eczema when he
asked about the marks. Complainant understands ring worm and
believes it is caused by poor hygiene and Youth A had eczema
when younger but has outgrown most of it as he has aged.
Complainant observed a rash on Youth A’s mouth and believes
Youth A obtained the rash when he rolled around on his bed.
Complainant reported being given a doctors summary dated
5/25/23 when asking for documentation of medical care. Case
Manager informed Complainant of Youth A’s sensitive skin as a
reason for the sever eczema on his skin. Complainant ended by
reporting a staff was fired after pushing Youth A to the ground. An
investigation (2023C0000127) was completed on 1/19/23 with no
findings on this reported concern.
MDHHS Worker was interviewed via phone on 10/4/2023. She
reported Youth A is on her caseload and was placed at the facility
in May 2022. Youth A was placed at this specific facility because
he is severely developmentally delayed, autistic, and non-verbal.
Youth A has done very well in the program, and she last observed
him on Thursday September 28, 2023. She denied observing the
mark on his head or other marks on his lower body. She reported
Youth A has always had eczema over his body and Youth A’s
mother informed MDHHS Worker Youth A has had severe
eczema throughout his life. Youth A’s eczema gets worst in the
winter and the doctor who examined Youth A, diagnosed Youth A
with eczema. MDHHS Worker reported Youth A is to use special
soap to help with the eczema and Youth A has a history of biting
himself and banging his head which has led to him having to wear
a helmet at times. She reported Youth A has Pica and will put
everything and anything in his mouth. She reported having no
concerns about Youth A’s care at the facility and has not received
any complaints from Complainant in the past.
DCWL Worker 2 was interviewed via phone on 10/4/2023. She
has never observed any marks on Youth A during her numerous
visits to the facility.
Youth A was observed face to face at the facility on 10/5/23 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A is nonverbal but his
3

interactions with staff were appropriate. He appeared well cared
for and was very active. His room was clean and well furnished.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
10/5/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
Youth A has been appropriately cared for during his time at the
facility.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
10/5/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
receiving a text message (unable to recall who sent the message),
that Complainant was not happy about something with Youth A.
He went to the location of Youth A and was informed by Case
Manager that Complainant had been disrespectful and upset
towards staff. Supervisor 1 reported Case Manager was unable to
recall what Complainant specifically said but she feared for her
safety. Case Manager told Supervisor 1, Complainant said he was
upset over Youth A having ringworm and Complainant began to
demand documentation of Youth A’s doctor appointments.
Complainant was also challenging the doctor’s diagnoses of Youth
A having eczema stating he didn’t believe Youth A has eczema
but rather ringworm all over his body. Case Manager informed
Supervisor 1 she gave Complainant documentation of the doctor’s
latest evaluation of Youth A. Supervisor 1 reported not working
with Youth A much but understands he is taking his medication
and has very sensitive skin resulting in the eczema.
Nurse Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility
on 10/5/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
Case Manager asked Nurse Supervisor to speak to Complainant.
Nurse Supervisor reported she was unable to speak because
Complainant kept talking over her and telling her she didn’t know
anything about caring for Youth A. Nurse Supervisor reported
there is a bruise assessment completed on Youth A weekly and
the doctor has been treating Youth A along with the facility for
eczema. Youth A had a doctor’s appointment yesterday and once
observing the mark on Youth A’s head, Youth A will be treated for
ringworm for the mark on his head. When Nurse Supervisor spoke
with Complainant, he told her to leave because Nurse
Supervisor’s opinion doesn’t matter to him. She denied observing
any mark on Youth A’s head when she examined him last
Thursday but reported (unidentified) staff saw the mark sometime
prior to Thursday when showering Youth A. Youth A has skin
issues and is very sensitive to things so they provide lotion twice a
day and several other lotions following a shower. They will start
the new medication as soon as the pharmacy provides it as
4

prescribed by the doctor following yesterday’s doctor’s
appointment.
Case Manager was interviewed face to face at the facility on
10/5/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported on
Tuesday of this week Complainant talked about a rash on Youth
A’s arms and head. Complainant had just cut Youth A’s hair and
gave him a shower. He was upset and told her he should take
Youth A home. Complainant told Case Manager to get the nurse
because Case Manager was unsure what made the mark on
Youth A’s head. After Complainant was done speaking to Nurse
Supervisor, Complainant requested Youth A’s medical records.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
10/5/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
because of Youth A’s significant development delays, staff must
“do everything for him”. She reported Youth A has very sensitive
skin and has numerous marks and bruises on his skin all of the
time. His skin will turn red from the heat of the water during a
shower. Youth A has eczema and because of the mark, Youth A
will scratch it and have an open wound. She reported staff apply
medication for Youth A’s skin condition and they have just
switched to a triple antibiotic ointment. Youth A will wipe off the
ointment, but staff are putting it back on as much as possible.
Supervisor 2 reported staff just found out yesterday following the
doctor’s appointment for Youth A that the mark on his head is
ringworm while the other marks on his body are eczema. Youth A
was observed by a different doctor yesterday. Supervisor 2 was
present when Complainant visited earlier in the week.
Complainant began to complain once observing the marks on
Youth A following a shower. Youth A’s father said this is the worst
he has witnessed since Youth A has been in care and Supervisor
2 got Case Manager.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 10/5/23
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported first working
with Youth A as his ABA therapist before changing her position at
the facility. She now works as a Direct Support Professional at the
facility. She reported Youth A has made significant progress in his
ability to communicate since being placed at the facility. He is able
to point or use pictures to communicate with others and is now
able to follow more directions. She reported providing ointment for
Youth A when he begins scratching or after taking a shower and
understands the ringworm is treated with an oral medication.
5

Nurse was interviewed face to face at the facility on 10/5/23 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported providing
nursing services to Youth A. Youth A has very sensitive skin that
requires special attention in his care. Different clothing can affect
him negatively and the facility uses special laundry detergent.
Youth A’s medication was changed to help with the chronic
eczema which is covering Youth A’s body.
Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4, Staff 5, Staff 6, Staff 7, Staff 8,
Staff 9, Staff 10, Staff 11, Staff 13, Staff 14, Staff 15, Staff 16,
Staff 18, and Supervisor 4 were interviewed face to face at the
facility on 10/5/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. They
all reported the same process for providing medical care for Youth
A’s eczema, ringworm, and skin lesions. They all understood and
reported applying the appropriate ointment for Youth A’s eczema
and the oral medication for Youth A’s ringworm. All of these staff
reported taking similar action to keep Youth A from engaging in
self-harming behaviors by placing Youth A in a long sleeve shirt,
placing their hand or a pad between Youth A’s head and the wall
or floor.
Documents Reviewed:
Hope Network Behavioral Health Injury/Bruise Charts for
July, August, September, and October 2023. During these
months, it is documented Bodily checks on Youth A occur twice a
day every day and on different days it has occurred three times. It
is documented Youth A has had at several times, bite marks on
the back and front side of his left and right arms, bruising on his
legs, arms, feet, and torso with evidence of eczema on his legs,
arms, head, and back several times. It is also documented that the
eczema and other marks have been healing and ointment has
been applying to these areas. However, these marks then
reappear over time. Each log is signed off by the staff doing the
review and the staff coming on shift.
Nursing Treatment Notes 7/1/23 to 10/5/23. This document
outlines the treatment provided by the facility nursing staff and
when the nursing bruise assessments are completed. There is
documentation weekly of these assessments taking place. There
is also narrative about what is observed and the condition of
marks on his body.
Email dated 10/5/23 from Nursing Supervisor to all facility
staff for Youth A. Nursing Supervisor indicates Youth A’s doctor
has placed Youth A on a stronger steroid cream for the eczema
6

and “Griseofulvin” an oral liquid to cover the ringworm. The
Griseofulvin is currently not available but should be available no
later than 10/6/23. Staff are to use the new steroid on Youth A’s
eczema but also use gloves because of the steroid in the cream.
22 Incident Reports for Youth A starting on 4/16/23 and
ending with 9/27/23. These reports range from Youth A engaging
in self-harming behaviors such as biting self to banging his head
on the wall. There is also documentation of him scratching his
rash until it bleeds. In each case, staff respond as required and
medical care was provided.
Hope Network Medication Administration and Control C-
117.BHW dated 7/15/21. This policy outlines the administering
medication to youth who do not independently administer their
own medication. Staff who are administering the medication are to
remain with the youth until all of the medication has been
swallowed. Staff are to record all medications given or refused. All
medications discovered to be missing must immediately be
reported to the Program Manager or Program Nurse. An incident
report must be completed for any missing medications. Staff can
dispose no controlled medications with a witness.
Hope Network Medication and Adverse Reactions C-118.BHW
dated 1/13/20. This policy address consistency in reporting
medication errors and charting errors.
Hope Network Developmental Adolescent Residential
Treatment Health Services Policy and Procedure dated
10/23/20. This policy outlines the procedures for health services at
the facility. Staff are to follow the Incident Report policy/procedure
regarding documentation for incidents with medication.
Residential Updated Service Plans for Youth A were
reviewed. And it is documented Youth A’s medication for his ring
worm was added.
After Visit Summary for Youth A dated 10/18/2023. A
medication change was made to include “Triamcinolone Acetonide
(Kenalog) to be applied in thin layers twice daily to the affected
area. This is treatment for Youth A’s eczema. Youth A is to
continue using Griseofulvin microsize to treat the ringworm. He is
to take 22 ml by mouth daily for 42 days.
7

Medication Passes during October 2023 for Youth A. This
document outlines the medication provided to Youth A during the
month of October. Throughout October 2023, Youth A received
his medication are ordered with only one exception. On October
20, 2023 his medication for the ringworm was withheld per
hospital’s orders. Youth A had his sedated dental appointment at
the hospital on that day.
Trinity Health Saint Mary’s Hospital Pre-Admission Services
for the sedated dental appointment. This document states,
Youth may take only the following medications day of surgery with
a small sip of water – Abilify and clonidine day of surgery.
Flonase, Claritin and singular if needed.
Hope Network Behavioral Health Services Drug destruction
log. This document outlines the destruction of medication at the
facility. The medication found in Youth A’s room is listed in this
document. It is documented the medication (25mg Sertraline) was
destroyed on 6/11/23 with the method being “kitty litter” and
witnessed by two staff.
Team meeting minutes dated 6/13, 6/14, and 6/15/23. These
minutes document the situation with the medication pill found in
Youth A’s room by Complainant. Staff are informed to check
Youth B’s mouth when passing medication because Youth B may
have cheeked the medication found in Youth A’s room.
Human Resources file for Nurse Supervisor and Nurse were
reviewed. Neither had disciplinary action documented in their HR
file. Training documents indicate both are current with training.
Analysis Based upon interviews and written documentation there is no
evidence that supports Youth A did not receive appropriate
medical treatment as required while in the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4407 Facility and premises maintenance.
Section (1) A facility and premises shall be maintained in a clean,
Description comfortable, and safe condition. The facility shall be located on
land that is properly drained.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A's room, bedding, and toys are dirty.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via phone on 10/4/2023.
Complainant reported Youth A only plays with shoestrings and his
tennis shoes rather than the other toys in the room. Youth A’s
shoes and shoestrings are dirty as are the toys in the room and
8

the room in general. Complainant also reported being told Youth
A’s bedroom is cleaned daily but he believes the floor doesn’t look
like it was cleaned.
MDHHS Worker was interviewed via phone on 10/4/2023.
MDHHS Worker reported never observing Youth A’s room as dirty
but described the room as messy because of his toys all over the
floor. There is no food, trash, or feces in the room at any time she
was present in the room. Only once in past did Youth A smear
feces on the walls of his room which occurred several months
ago.
DCWL Worker 1 was interviewed via phone on 10/4/2023. She
reported investigating an incident in which staff were reported to
have mistreated Youth A in December 2022 Special Investigation
2023C0000127. She also reported being in Youth A’s room and
finding it clean and having no concerns about the condition and
appearance of Youth A.
DCWL Worker 2 was interviewed via phone on 10/4/2023. She
reported being the primary consultant for the facility and has been
involved in numerous unannounced visits to the facility. She
reported having no concerns about the cleanliness of the facility or
Youth A’s room.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
10/5/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She denied the
room was dirty. If Youth A was smearing feces in his room, the
cleaning of the room would reach a different level that is called a
“deep cleaning”. This would involve all items (toys) in the room
cleaned daily.
Nurse Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility
on 10/5/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Nurse
Supervisor reported the bedroom is cleaned daily with a mop and
the washing of surfaces. She was unsure of the time frame for
toys but reported the assistant program managers are responsible
to ensure the cleaning takes place.
Case Manager was interviewed face to face at the facility on
10/5/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
observing staff mop Youth A’s room earlier in the day as required
and believed the room had toys laying around but was clean.
Case Manager shared the daily schedule for Youth A which
included Youth A getting up early and taking a shower each
9

morning. Staff will clean his room while he sits on his bed working
with his shoelaces and backpack.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
10/5/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Supervisor 2
reported Youth A’s bedding is changed daily, and his room is
sweep and mopped daily each morning. If Youth A has a bowel
movement in the room and feces gets out of his pullups during the
changing, the room will be cleaned again, and the toys cleaned in
the tub. She also reported toys are cleaned weekly but was
uncertain of the day and noted the Shift Supervisor is responsible
for this action. She has never observed Youth A’s room in a filthy
condition.
Nurse, Supervisor 3, Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4, Staff 5,
Staff 6, Staff 7, Staff 8, Staff 9, Staff 10, Staff 11, Staff 13, Staff
14, Staff 15, Staff 16, and Staff 18 were interviewed face to
face at the facility on 10/5/23 in collaboration with MDHHS
worker. All of these staff reported the same room cleaning
process as the room being mopped daily, sheets and bedding
replaced daily, and flat surfaces wiped clean daily. All understood
there to be sanitizing chemical in the mop water and if Youth A
was to have a bowel movement in the room, the room was
cleaned again. Although, their reports of the toys being cleaned
and sanitized varied on the time frame, all reported the toys were
cleaned especially if observed to be dirty.
Tour Observation
The facility and Youth A’s room were observed and found to be
appropriately furnished and clean. The floor in his room is a
mixture of light and dark brown which can be misinterpreted as not
being clean but upon closer inspection, it appeared to be clean.
Overall, the facility is clean and appears to have appropriate
maintenance.
Analysis Based upon interviews and observation there is no evidence that
supports the facility is not keeping Youth A’s room and other areas
of the facility maintained clean, comfortable, and safely.
Technical Assistance:
It was recommended the facility develop an updated method of
cleaning the floors in youth’s bedrooms. They are using chemical
to sanitize the floors and other areas they wipe with chemical
based water, the possibility of a youth ingesting the chemical is
increased. This is especially true with Youth A who has been
diagnoses with Pica in the past.
10

It was recommended the facility develop a method of documenting
the cleaning of the youth’s rooms and the facility in whole.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4149 Resident nutrition.
Section (1) A licensee shall provide a minimum of 3 nutritious edible meals
Description daily unless medically contraindicated and documented.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are not providing meals to Youth A after he refuses to eat a
meal. Youth A has lost weight because he is not eating.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via phone on 10/4/2023.
Complainant reported that if Youth A doesn’t want to eat a meal,
staff will not bring him food later because they refuse to take food
out of the cafeteria. Staff are requiring Youth A to use signs to
express being hungry and if Youth A doesn’t point to a sign staff
just don’t feed him. Complainant also reported Youth A normally
eats two breakfasts but will miss lunch each day. Youth A looks
malnourished and has lost a lot of weight.
MDHHS Worker was interviewed via phone on 10/4/2023.
MDHHS Worker reported Youth A has not lost weight as reported
by Complainant and Youth A does eat daily. The staff has taught
Youth A to point at a picture of food when he wants to eat, and he
can receive a snack every 15-minutes if he wants. If Youth A
doesn’t eat a meal, staff will leave a tray available for him and she
has never had any concerns about Youth A receiving appropriate
nutrition.
Case Manager was interviewed face to face at the facility on
10/5/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Case Manager
reported Youth A will eat throughout the day and uses signs or
pointing to let staff know he is hungry. This is a technique he has
learned in his ABA therapy. Youth A is allowed a snack whenever
he request one.
Supervisor 3, Supervisor 4, Staff 2, Staff 8, Staff 9, Staff 10,
Staff 11, Staff 13, Staff 14, Staff 15, and Staff 16 were
interviewed face to face at the facility on 10/5/23 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. These staff all reported
Youth A will use pictures or point to communicate when he is
hungry. They also reported Youth A is offered three meals a day
and snacks when he requests. If Youth A refuses a meal, he has
the option to have the food of the refused meal until the next meal
is available. Staff all report Youth A is never denied food. Youth A
11

is offered a snack every 15-minutes or if he requests by pointing
at the food as taught by the ABA.
Documents Reviewed:
Meals Data for Youth A dated 6/1/23 to 10/16/23. This
document outlines the meals offered to Youth A on the different
shifts. The staff assigned to Youth A is identified, the type of meal
(breakfast, lunch, dinner, and snack) is identified, and Youth A’s
response such as accepting the meal or refusal of the meal is
identified. The shift the action takes place is also identified.
Overall, the document outlines Youth A had eaten a majority of his
meals (breakfast, lunch, dinner, and snacks) with a small
percentage of rejecting the meal.
Initial Nursing Assessment 3/21/22 for Youth A. This document
outlines Youth A’s physical condition at time of his admission to
the facility. Youth A is documented as weighing 58 pounds and a
height of 48.50 inches.
Helen DeVos Children’s hospital After Visit Summary for
Youth A dated 10/18/2023. Youth A’s weight was documented at
61 pounds and 1.1 ounces.
D.A.R.T. Youth A medical vitals 6/1/23 to 10/11/23. During this
time period, Youth A weighed 59 pounds on 6/8/23 and weighed
58 pounds on 10/11/23. Over the course of this time period his
weight is documented to range from 57 pounds to 59 pounds. His
lowest weight of 57 pounds is documented to have occurred on
6/27/23, 7/28/23, and 8/28/23.
Corrective Action Plan for Special Investigation
2020C0103039 dated 10/14/2020. The plan documents a
“procedure for proper documentation of meals” was written,
reviewed with staff, and included in office binders and orientation
binders.
Meals Documentation Procedure without a date. This
document outlines the process staff are to use to document a
youth’s food intake. Meal consumption or refusal is to be logged
for each youth for each meal provided. If the youth displayed a
consistent food consumption issue, Nursing are to implement a
food tracker and consult with a BCBA. Staff are to complete a
“ECare food log” each shift for each youth. Staff are also to
complete the “Food Acceptance Data Sheet” each shift when
deemed necessary by the Clinical Supervisor and Nursing
12

Department. When completing the Food Acceptance Data Sheet,
for each meal, staff are to list the food item consumed with the
appropriate proportion for all food offered. If the youth has the
need for proportion documentation the Nursing staff will monitor
and review data sheets weekly.
Analysis Based upon interviews and written documentation there is no
evidence that supports the facility is not providing at least 3
nutritious edible meals per day. Evidence supports that Youth A
can refuse a meal but can also obtain a snack when he wants.
Additionally, his weight has maintained throughout his stay at
DART ranging from 57-61 pounds.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section Rule 126. The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
Description administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff
on duty to perform the prescribed functions required by these
administrative rules and in the agency’s program statement and to
provide for the continual needs, protection, and supervision of
residents
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth A was on 1:1 supervision with Staff 19 when he was able to
enter the laundry area and take a sip of laundry detergent without
Staff 19 being aware of Youth A’s actions.
Investigation Administrator 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
10/5/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Administrator 1
was interviewed again via phone on 10/27/23. She reported
staff switch responsibilities of supervision at times. She reported
Staff 5 had the regular ratio of 1:2 when she switched with Staff 19
who was on a ratio of 1:1 with Youth A. She indicated there
appears to be a communication break down between Staff 5 and
Staff 19 causing the incident where Youth A was able to entry the
laundry area and take a sip of laundry detergent.
Staff 1, Staff 3, Staff 6, Staff 7, Staff 14, Staff 18 were
interviewed face to face at the facility on 10/5/23 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. All of these staff reported
Youth A is on one-to-one supervision which means staff are
always be with him, either in his room or sitting outside of his
room.
Staff 4 and Staff 12 were interviewed face to face at the
facility on 10/19/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Both
reported working third shift and providing 1:1 supervision for Youth
A when Youth A is awake. They complete the variable interval
13

room checks within a 15-minute limit and makes sure to make eye
contact of Youth A when checking him.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 10/19/23
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported working first
shift and being assigned to Youth A on Wednesdays. She
described her supervision as keeping eyes and ears on him
through the whole 10-hour shift. If Youth A is in his room, at times
she will sit outside of his door and listen to him. When this occurs,
she will do room checks on him in a variable interval within a 15-
minute time frame. She will compete these room checks even
